abstract.p: Britain reports its first trade surplus with European Union countries since November 1995, or before euro was introduced as common currency; for August, surplus was less than 100 million pounds, or $145 million, compared with deficit of 300 million pounds in July; worldwide, Britain records trade deficit for goods and services of 1.4 billion pounds, compared with 2.1 billion pound deficit in July (S)

block.p: Britain reported its first trade surplus with European Union countries since November 1995, or before the euro was introduced as a common currency. For August, the surplus was less than $:100 million, or $145 million, compared with a deficit of $:300 million in July, according to the Office of National Statistics. The reversal comes as the euro continues its slide against sterling, and belies commonly held beliefs among British manufacturers that they are at a disadvantage against European companies given the euro's relative weakness. Worldwide, Britain recorded a trade deficit for goods and services of $:1.4 billion, compared with a $:2.1 billion deficit in July.
